summary: This document is an email chain from February 13, 2020, discussing a press inquiry from the Financial Times regarding the UK Financial Conduct Authority's (FCA) investigation into Barclays CEO Jes Staley's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. The emails show coordination between US and UK authorities to avoid public comment on the investigation.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.context: Subject of a UK FCA and PRA investigation regarding his statements about his links to Jeffrey Epstein, as disclosed by Barclays.

persons.name: Kadhim Shubber
persons.context: Journalist who made a press inquiry to the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) about information passed to UK authorities regarding Staley and Epstein.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Colleague at the UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) who is to be contacted with any updates while the primary manager is out of office.

connections.description: The UK FCA is investigating Staley's statements about his 'links to' or 'relationship with' Epstein, as referenced in the press inquiry.

The email chain indicates communication and coordination between the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the UK Financial Conduct Authority regarding the Staley/Epstein matter.

events.title: Barclays Discloses FCA/PRA Investigation
events.description: Barclays Bank publicly discloses that the UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) are investigating CEO Jes Staley's statements about his links to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Financial Times Press Inquiry
events.description: Financial Times reporter Kadhim Shubber contacts the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) seeking comment or background on information the DOJ passed to UK authorities about Staley and Epstein.

locations: Stratford, London, E20 1JN, United Kingdom (FCA/Payment Systems Regulator office)
keyFacts: Barclays Bank publicly disclosed on February 13, 2020, that UK regulators (FCA and PRA) were investigating CEO Jes Staley's statements about his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.
The US Department of Justice had passed information to the UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) regarding Staley's relationship with Epstein, prompting a press inquiry from the Financial Times.
Both US and UK authorities (USANYS and FCA) coordinated to not provide any public comment on the investigation or the information shared.
The email chain is marked 'Strictly private and confidential' and 'FCA Restricted,' indicating the sensitive nature of the regulatory investigation and inter-agency communications.
